animalOfTheDay.name: sea lion
facts: Sea lions can dive up to 900 feet and hold their breath for 10 minutes.
They are highly social and communicate through barks, growls, and body language.
Sea lions can rotate their hind flippers forward to walk on land.
They are intelligent and can be trained to perform complex tasks.

calendar.name: salmon
facts: Salmon are anadromous, meaning they migrate from saltwater to freshwater to spawn.
They use Earth's magnetic field and smell to navigate back to their birthplace.
Salmon are a keystone species, providing nutrients to forests when their carcasses decompose.
After spawning, most Pacific salmon die, while some Atlantic salmon may survive to spawn again.

calendar.name: sand dollar
facts: Sand dollars are flat sea urchins that live on the ocean floor.
The five-petal pattern seen on dead sand dollars is actually their skeletal structure.
They feed by filtering tiny particles of food from the sand using their tube feet.
When alive, they are covered in tiny, velvety spines that help them move and feed.

calendar.name: sandpiper
facts: Sandpipers are shorebirds with long bills for probing sand and mud for food.
Sandpipers have specialized bills that can sense vibrations of prey underground.
They perform elaborate aerial displays during courtship.
Some species undertake incredible migrations, flying nonstop for days over open ocean.

calendar.name: sardine
facts: Sardines swim in massive schools that can contain millions of fish.
They are an important food source for many marine predators, including whales and dolphins.
They are rich in omega-3 fatty acids and are an important commercial fish.
Sardines get their name from the Italian island of Sardinia where they were once abundant.

calendar.name: scorpion
facts: Scorpions give birth to live young, which ride on their mother's back until their first molt.
They can survive for months without food by slowing their metabolism.
Only about 25 of the 1,500+ scorpion species have venom deadly to humans.
Scorpions glow under ultraviolet light due to fluorescent chemicals in their exoskeletons.

calendar.name: sea cucumber
facts: They play a crucial role in ocean ecosystems by recycling nutrients on the seafloor.
They breathe through their anus by pumping water in and out of their respiratory tree.
Sea cucumbers can eject their internal organs as a defense mechanism and later regenerate them.
Some species can liquefy their bodies to squeeze through small spaces.

calendar.name: sea lion
facts: Sea lions can dive up to 900 feet and hold their breath for 10 minutes.
They are intelligent and can be trained to perform complex tasks.
They are highly social and communicate through barks, growls, and body language.
Sea lions can rotate their hind flippers forward to walk on land.

randomAnimals.name: zebu
facts: Their loose skin helps dissipate heat in tropical climates.
Zebus have humps storing fat for drought survival – not water.
They sweat insect-repellent oils and tolerate heat better than European cattle.
Zebu are sacred in India – 330 million gods are said to live in each.

randomAnimals.name: lizard
facts: Some lizards, like the chameleon, can change color for camouflage or communication.
The smallest lizard, the Jaragua sphaero, is only 16 mm long.
Lizards can detach their tails to escape predators, a process called autotomy.
Komodo dragons are the largest lizards, growing up to 10 feet in length.

randomAnimals.name: cat
facts: A group of cats is called a 'clowder' and a group of kittens is a 'kindle'.
Cats can rotate their ears 180 degrees to pinpoint sounds.
They have a third eyelid called a nictitating membrane for protection.
Cats spend 70% of their lives sleeping, which is 13-16 hours a day.
